The three candidates for Student Council President, Bob
Nelson, Amy Sandusky, and Art
Yoon, stated their campaign platforms on Monday night in the
Glass Pavilion, along with candidates for the other offices. The
following is a condensation of
separate interviews with the
respective candidates.
Amy Sandusky, a sophomore
biology major from Johnstown,
Pennsylvania, has served on the
Council for two years. As a student liaison for the English as a
Second Language program, she
has attended and participated in
classes designed to help foreign
teaching assistants learn the
language as well as American
college student slang. She has
also sat on a number of ad hoc
committees, most notably the
Armstrong Committee, which
she feels is increasing open communication between students and
the Administration. As a result of
these experiences, one of her
main campaign planks is open
communication
on
the
Homewood campus: "I feel that
good, open communication starts

in the classroom and extends well
beyond. We are finally starting to.
reach the Administration and are
making progress toward a more
open campus. Better communication means a better education. I
hope to keep this progress going
through persistence if elected."
News-Letter: What do you feel
can he done about next year's 3%
tuition hike?
Amy Sandusky: Well, I feel that
it's not unreasonable to include a
"student" trustee, not a "young"
trustee, on the Board when so
many other schools have student
trustees. Finally, there could be
some student input on important
University decisions. What I
think is more ridiculous is the
50% tuition hike for summer
school intro-level science
courses. When the University
tries to make a profit from the
summer school to put into Arts
and Sciences and other schools,
its thoughts are in the right direction, but 50% is too stiff. At this
point, there's not much we can do
about the 3% hike until we get
such representation as a student
trustee.
N-L: Where do you stand on centralization of the Hopkins

schools?
A.S.: I definitely feel that centralization of the schools would
benefit everyone. I know that
centralizing department budgets
would cut down on interdepartmental strife and disproportional
funding and, most importantly,
improve communication and the
quality of our education. There's
no reason why Arts and Sciences
should be getting as little as it is,
even with future grants.
N-L: The Five-Year Plan's effects
have been felt all over campus.
What do you feel can be done to
stave off its negative effects?
A.S.: Nobody benefits from having to sit or even stand in aisles
for classes. That's not a way to
learn. When we consider how
much our education costs, it's
ridiculous to have more TA's
than professors. We're all paying
for these professors, aren't we?
I'm very hopeful with a new
University president coming we
can change this trend together.
There needs to be a serious fiscal
overhaul and I'm confident that
we can work with the new Administration to change these problems into smaller classes and

APL designs "Star Wars" tracking satellite
by Martin Stemmler
The Hopkins Applied Physics
Laboratory (APL) in Laurel,
Maryland, is currently analyzing
data from a successful satellite
tracking experiment for the
Strategic Defense Initiative, commonly known as 'Star Wars,' or
SDI.
Crucial to the success of the
SDI shield against nuclear
weapons is the quick and accurate
detection and tracking of Soviet
or Chinese nuclear missile launches. In the boost phase of a
nuclear missile's journey into orbit, the rocket exhausts hot gases
in a plume. These gases are
detectable primarily in the infrared region. Under an SDI umbrella, these rocket plumes,
known as the "signature" of the
missile, would be detected by

satellites. These satellites would
then guide other weapons to
destroy the missiles.
APL's Delta Star project was
designed to address these
issues—in the Pentagon's jargon,
Surveillance, Acquisition, Tracking, and Kilt Assessment
(SATKA). The News-Letter interviewed APL's Delta Star project manager for this article. Additional information was provided by APL's external relations officer, Frank Proctor.
The Delta Star 183 satellite,
which was designed and assembled in Laurel at APL, was launched on March 24, 1989 on a
Delta
McDonnell-Douglas
rocket. The Delta booster is the
military's preferred vehicle for
space missions. While in low
earth orbit, the Delta Star satellite
collected data on gaseous plumes

emitted by sounding rockets launched from Wallops Island,
Virginia, and from Alaska. The
plumes were designed to simulate
the rocket plumes of Soviet intercontinental and submarinelaunched ballistic missiles. Data
collection ended on December
21, 1989, six months past the intended lifetime of the satellite.
The Delta Star satellite's sensors measured the rocket plumes'
radiation
characteristics
throughout
the
optical
spectrum--infrared, visible, and
ultraviolet ranges. Past SDI
research has focused on the infrared, which is the dominant
wavelength. The infrared region
becomes even more important as
the missile cools down in midcourse, the temperature being inversely related to the most intense

The last issue the Spectator
came under fire for running the
cartoon "2x +1" by artist Bill
Podurgiel, which denigrated
female undergraduates at
Hopkins. Members of the
Women's Center indicated that
"this was not a production worthy of an intellectual establishment such as ours." The cartoon
was deemed so offensive that the
administration took action.
Dean of Students Susan
Boswell, who sent out a memo to
all Hopkins students on the matter, said, "The letter was signed
by the four deans, not just myself,
the rationale being that things like
that had become too common on
campus and outraged students
demanded us to act. A request
was made by the SAC that the
Spectator not print any more offensive materials of that nature."
Editor Brian Kennedy and
Associate Editor Jon Miller were
unavailable for comment, but
staff member and former
Associate Editor for the SpectatorJim Marino said, "It was
perfectly all right for people to
voice their dissatisfaction with the
cartoon—but groundless accusations and heavy-handed tactics
such as censorship are not fair.
People who voiced their concerns
in the News-Letter should have
contacted one of us, which would
have provided a more conductive
environment. The administration
handled this improperly, and
basically made an attempt at
intimidation."

The Punchline
By Christopher T. McColl
The punchline is this: the scrapheap.
I have tons of work to do, and
I really don't have time to write
a thematically sound column, so
this week's installment will consist of all those ideas that I'd really like to develop into complete
columns, but can't for whatever
reason.
I guess thematically, we could
call it "Those Aspects of Human
Existence that Chris Finds Most
Peculiar."
One of the most peculiar
things, for me, at least, is the fact
that facial tissue is about four
times the size of bathroom
tissue—and twice as thick. Consider this: you get an eight-inch
by eight-inch four-ply square for
your nose (the biggest honker requiring maybe ten square inches
at most) but you get a four-byfour one-ply square, albeit a
rough ply most of the time, for
your derriere (I won't speculate
on what size the largest tush
might need).
Number two: snarfing. It is
said that in some countries, it is
common courtesy to belch after
a good meal, and most
Americans, I think, would find
that gross. By the same token,
however, I have found that many
Americans consider it a tremendous achievement if they can get
one of their close friends to snarf
at a meal, an achievement worthy of countless anecdotal repetitions to those other close friends
who might have missed the event.
Editor's Note to those Belching
Visitors to Our Fine Country
Who Might Not Know What the
Verb "To Snarf" Means, Let
Alone How to Conjugate It: It is
an odd fact of the human anatomy
that when faced with possible
asphyxiation by combining
laughter with commonly imbibed fluids, the brain has the ability to register the embarassment
factor of said fluid in the event of
death (i.e. it is much cooler to die
"choking violently on a dry martini" than to die "gagging,
moustache-laden, on 2% milk.").

Given that a particular drink is
just too hysterical to let somebody
die on, the brain will cause a sudden and jarring peristaltic twitch,
forcing said drink back up,
hopefully, through the mouth. In
the event that this mouth is not
busy laughing, the result will be
a "saliva tocarum," more commonly called a "spit take." If the
mouth is laughing, however, the
tongue will be pressed against the
esophagus, and the drink will be
forced out another egress, namely, the nose. The passage from
esophagus to nose is an intricate
one, filled with many organs
designed to transform ordinary
food into mucous-based lifeforms. The emergence of these
life-forms is "snarfing."
Third, of course, is elevatorbutton-punching, best illustrated
thusly: Person approaches
Elevator. Person pushes "up"
button, thus alerting Elevator of
his/her presence. Elevator, on
another floor, may take ten or
twelve seconds to arrive. Person,
angered that Elevator was not
notified earlier of his arrival,
strikes on the notion that perhaps
pressing the "up" button 9,000
more times will make it arrive
faster. This act is usually coupled with a glance up at the ceiling
in order that Person, capable of
vision through solids, might
watch Elevator's hurried approach. This activity was what
prompted me to submit the
Stupidity Bill to Congress, in
order to mandate a "Slap Law."
The "Slap Law" gives
pedestrians the rights and responsibilities of deputies when acts of
stupidity are witnessed. A
pedestrian witnessing someone in
front of an elevator, for example,
tapping the drum solo to
"Wipeout" on the call button
with head upturned, would have
the duty of stopping the person
immediately and slapping him or
her across the face, winning
another battle in the war against
stupidity.

The Women's Center woulo
like to address the many
misconceptions and accusations
concerning the "2x +1" cartoon
strip. As stated several times, the
group of students who went to the
administration went on their own
behalf, and not as representatives
of the Women's Center. This
represents a positive trend in the
attitude of the student body, that
individuals would feel strongly
enough about something that affected them personally to do
something about it, and that they
would feel comfortable enough to
go to an administrator and voice
their concerns.
The Women's Center sent out
a flyer asking the Hopkins community if they thought this cartoon was appropriate, and we
stand behind this action. The flyer
was offensive only to the extent
that the cartoon was offensive,
but at least in the context of the
flyer the attitude was questioned,
rather than accepted.
The members of the Women's
Center are dismayed to find that
instead of addressing the issue of
sexism that this cartoon presents,
this campus has successfully
thrown up a smoke screen in the
guise of the censorship issue.
Focusing the argument on censorship is convenient in that no one
is threatened, except perhaps the
editors of campus publications.
The fact is that many people are
uncomfortable discussing issues
of discrimination because of the
basic reality that in order to provide equality, the dominating
group will have to relinquish
some of its precious control.
Whether we are referring to an
Aryan race or a patriarchy, those
who dominate will try to avoid
discussing the issue.
The issue here is sexism, and
it is so pervasive and omnipresent
that we have trouble identifying
it as such, much less addressing
it constructively in the form of
dialogue within this intellectual
community. If this strip had
targeted any other minority group
on campus, it would not have

been printed.
Evidently there was another
cartoon by the same artist submitted to the Spectator, but because
of space restrictions it was not
printed. The alternative strip
presented an issue similar to the
one in the printed cartoon, but it
was aimed at the men of Johns
Hopkins instead of the women.
The editors of the Spectator chose
the cartoon that they found to be
the most humorous. Obviously it
is funnier, or more accepted, to
mock women than men.
The cartoon itself was meant to
offend. The artist even told us to
whom we should address hate
mail. We question the intent of
this article. It seems that there
must be more mature and meaningful ways to address the issue
of sexism, if dialogue among the
community is truly the intent. The
idea that women should be judged by their looks rather than their
intelligence is blatantly sexist and
discriminatory. Threatened by intelligent women, some people attempt to diminish their worth by
using the media's argument that
a woman's value is determinined by her looks. Seemingly innocent remarks or jokes such as this
are the most pervasive forms of
discrimination today. By unconsciously accepting these views
we reinforce our learned biases.
By laughing at African
Americans, Jews, Puerto Ricans,
homosexuals, and women we are
subordinating these groups. We
hope that any future discussion of
the "2x +1" article will focus on
the real issue at hand.
Finally, the Women's Center's
primary goal is not to accuse. We
are a resource center for anyone
interested in women's issues.
March is International Women's
,Month and we will be sponsoring several events to celebrate
women's solidarity. Although
problems of sexism still exist, we
would like to encourage a more
positive approach to women's
issues, and we invite you all(men
and women alike) to attend our
upcoming events.

PUNCH, from 5
My fourth thesis refers to the
habit so many people have of
reacting to weekly television
series in which the main character
is placed in some sort of peril,
such as MacGyver's weekly stint
with a laser aimed at his pancreas
and the like. Anyone honestly
tense in moments like this might
consult his TV Guide. If the
show's slated to appear the
following week, and especially if
it's still called "MacGyver,"
chances are he'll muddle through.
Interruptive question: Is there
going to be a "fortysomething"

episode on the tenth anniversary
of "thirtysomething'"? Or is this
really "Pippi Longstocking Goes
Into Advertising and Social
Activisomething'"?
Last is the inclination everyone
seems to feel to peel the
wax/foam label off a soda bottle
when it's empty. I have recently
been informed that this stems out
of a feeling of social frustration.
I have a feeling that the idea
started with the same group of
people who spread around the
"chewing ice is said to be a sign
of sexual frustration" myth. My
hypothesis concerning this group

is that they all look like toads and
couldn't find a date if they bought
a calendar, but have trained
themselves through aversion
therapy and acupuncture not to
peel labels off bottles and not to
chew ice when their soda is gone;
that way, they could all claim to
be more carnally rampant than
their truly satisfied friends. My
suggestion for these people is to
stop sticking themselves with pins
and live wires—they'll be more
attractive, and the rest of us will
be able to get back to our nervous
habits without feeling selfconscious.

FIVE-YEAR PLAN
Some grad students have been
concerned of late as to whether
the GRO will get a chance to meet
the new University President, Dr.
William C. Richardson. Apparently, according to Joanne
Houlahan, this should be possible. Further, she said, her discussions as part of the Armstrong
committee had led her to believe
that Richardson has a keen interest in revamping the teaching
of graduate students at Hopkins.
especially with .a view to getting
PhD students, through quicker.
This however brings one to the
problem of what many perceive
de eartIS a trend towards man

ments' becoming little more than
"service departments," meaning
that they are concerned with
churning out undergrads as
quickly as possible with little emphasis on new research. Departments that have particularly
suffered, it is generally agreed,
include the language departments
and Biology. The latter used once
to require a lab for each class at
the undergrad level. Now the
students can get away with taking only two lab classes for the
B.A., and they are only required
fro those taking classes to get into med school.
This problem has been intensified by the five-year plan's enforcement of a ten percent cut in
faculty numbers, to be acheived
through attrition. Thus important
vacancies may well remain unfilled. Certainly, they will not be
automatically filled. As things
stand now, since the implementation of the plan, departments
with recent vacancies must petition to have them filled. Arts &
Sciences Dean Lloyd Armstrong
decides each case on an ad hoc
basis. To say the least, this would
certainly seem to go against the
grain of what incoming-president
Richardson is purported to want.
The bind the school finds itself
in is simple. Undergrads provide
revenue. Grads do not.
Moreover, some subjects are currently in high demand with
undergrads, such as International
Relations. The school is therefore
pressure—economic
under
pressure, if nothing else—to let
undergrads into these majors in
greater numbers as a way of increasing the cash flowing into
Arts & Sciences. So far, so good.
The problem lies in the fact that
Hopkins' reputation is built on its
status as a research institution,
rather than a place of teaching.
Hopkins always has been, and
still is, a cross between a college
and a think-tank. But its name
rests on that think-tank component. However, other researchoriented establishments have far
larger endowments than Hopkins
has. We cannot afford not to
teach larger and larger numbers

_
of undergrads.
And yet we don't cio a particularly good job of it. For this
comes at a time when many professors are trying to shed some of
their advising responsibility due
to the amount of research time it
cuts into. Since 1975, there has
been a staggering 70 percent drop
in the proportion of undergrads
taking the honors option, which
includes for the most part an individually supervised senior
thesis. On top of this, the Office
of Acedemic Advising, which
does an excellent job under the
most adverse of circumstances, is
encouraging students to rely on
their own departments' council,
rather than the less specific advice
offered by Academic Advising.
In some departments, it has
become common for advising
responsibilities to be given over
to grad students; the profs no
longer have the time.
All of which puts more
pressure on the long-suffering
grad population. Smaller
stipends, because of financial
cuts. Greater teaching—and now,
advising—loads, because of the
ten-percent cut in faculty. Wayda
go, Steve.
The cumulative result will
simply be that Hopkins' name
plummets still further. Grad
students must no longer be taken
for granted. Hopkins must either
continue to let grads in at the current fairly high rate, while
guaranteeing them enough funding to get through their programs quickly, without having to
resort to teaching and outside jobs
to support themselves. Or it must
drastically reduce the number of
grads admitted, while agreeing to
fund them for longer as each grad
soaks up an inevitably larger
teaching load.
Either path will do. The current
one will not. For it is simply the
worst of all worlds.

$100,000 that they must pay out
of relatively low earnings. They
face a professional life that includes a public and lawyers eager
to sue, administrators in the
public and private sectors eager
to control, and worst of all, patients eager to be suspicious of
their doctor's ability and
motivation.
"Many doctors have told me
that when a new patient walks in
the door, their first thoughts are
directed not to finding out what
is wrong and how to help but
rather to wondering whether this
is another patient likely to bring
suit.
"Please do not misunderstand
my purpose in alerting you to the
anxiety that is developing among
doctors. Any profession with
power over our lives requires
sensible monitoring and public
scrutiny . .. But if we go so far
as to make our physicians sick at
heart, we do ourselves no favor
when the time comes for us to
seek their help."
"Dear Doctors:
Doctors, of course, have good
reasons to expect high incomes:
the long and arduous training, the
emotional and physical demands
of practice, the value of the services offered. But medical consumers, although able intellectually to acknowledge such
arguments, find it hard to accept
that they should pay for
something they did not want or
that anyone should make large
profits from their misery.
"Therefore, I have come to
believe that for the medical profession to preserve the public
trust, it is critical for doctors to
be studious and scrupulous in
avoiding any and all financial
conflicts of interest. I believe that
we should henceforth be encouraging the development of
nongovernmental practice arrangements based on salaries for
physicians, rather than fees.
"The financial environment

should consist of a salary well
above the national average [from
$90,000 to $100,000 starting
salaries with opportunities to advance to $200,000. And for those
who believe that doctors should
have the right to make much
more, like some business executives they know, I would
simply suggest that they go into
business]. I would also argue that
the salaries in all specialities
should be very similar, with
variation allowed only to account
for cost-of-living factors, number
of hours worked (especially at
night and on weekends), and
other differences in effort. This
should allow doctors to choose
specialties purely for reasons of
interest and suitability, not
because of financial incentives. I
would also stress the critical importance of eliminating financial
incentives from the opposite
direction, such as placing of
pressure on doctors to save
money by doing less for patients
than medical judgment would
otherwise dictate. Finally, we
should include building in incentives for patients to avoid unnecessary risks or demands."
The publication of these two
letters sparked many comments
from the medical community.
Norman Anderson, chairman of
admissions at the Johns Hopkins
School of Medicine, found the article to be too superficial. "What
does Dr. Johnson want this country to do? He wants everybody to
guarantee doctors honor and
trust, almost an open debit drawing on the checkbook from society, giving every doctor a
sizeable salary. He believes that
this in itself will solve the problem of society.
"He's failing to address a
much broader issue: the structure
of the health system, the burdens
Of where we are in dealing with
Inequities of physician distributions, inequities of distributions
of specialties and sub-specialties
care.
'The American Medical
Association has also done studies
to show that doctors' earnings
have gone down in the past
several years. Health care costs
continue to rise, unresponsive to
inflation or anything else. The
reasons, by in large, are the administrative bureaucratic components that have nothing to do
with taking care of the sick, but
are the billing, the re-billing, the
auditing, the validation, the oversight of the procedure. They have
clear evidence there is already
this tremendous bureaucracy of
non-workers who are really adding to the cost of today's health
care."
All the physicians I interviewed agreed that an improved health
care system is of utmost importance. Most of them do not
believe the government is doing
enough to alleviate the financial
burden that the American people
will have to shoulder in the near
future.
This concern and many others
were.addressed on February 11,
1990, at a symposium held at the
Glass Pavilion. Topics such as
"Sustaining Ethical Values in
Market Place Medicine,"
"Health Care Dilemmas in the
Third World," and "The Impact
of Social Problems Upon Doctors" provided a basis in which
the public can see what change
has taken place in the field of
medicine. One physician commented that a doctor these days
has two responsibilities: one to
heal the sick and the other to
direct the government into providing a system and financial support that will benefit the health of
Americans.
It is then not a wonder that
many students these days have
turned away from the field of
medicine. Many have turned
away from medicine because they
believe it not worth the years of
arduous training and the enormous debt when they are done.
John Gryder, pre-med auviser,
believes that "many people in
medicine have forgotten that it is
a service profession. They are
looking for monetary rewards and
these types of people are not appropriate for a profession in

which people expect them to
make sacrifices."
Reverend Clyde Shallenberger,
one of the speakers at the medical
sympositim, concurred with
Gryder's comment. "If money is
the primary motivation that drives
a student to medicine, then the
world is better off not having him
in medicine."
Many of the physicians including William Greenough, who
spent many years helping the
elderly in Bangladesh, and Jerry
Reardon, who gave a speech concerning the social problems faced by doctors, believe the
decrease in medical school applicants a positive change.
Greenough remarked, "The
decrease in medical applicants
will extract the students who are
not really right for the medical
profession."
Gryder spoke on the same lines
about Hopkins' pre-meds: "In all
honesty, I.think the decrease in
the number of applicants is good.
I see medical schools taking
students that they wouldn't have
taken in the past because their
grades weren't quite as high. You
don't have to be a genius to be a
good doctor. Getting 4.0 in
science courses is not a requirement for medical school. Because
the applicant pool is changing,
[admissions officers] are more
careful in looking at other
characteristics. Because of this
they are getting more students
that are suitable for the profession."

A new state sport for Md?
by Weijen Chang
Most Marylanders know that
the state bird is the oriole, that
the state flowet is the blackeyed susan, and that the state
sport is—jousting? While
many Marylanders might think
"lacrosse" would be a better
answer, jousting remains the
state sport of Maryland,
despite a recent attempt by
lacrosse advocates to give
lacrosse at least a share of
jousting's title.
Under pressure from State
Senate President Thomas
"Mike" Millc'. (D-Prince
Georges County), supporters
of a bill proposing to designate
lacrosse the state team sport
decided not to introduce it for
consideration by the legislature
this year. The bill, sponsored
by State Sen. Frank Kelly(DBaltimore County), would retain jousting as the state individual sport.
According to John Stude,
one of the bill's chief supporters, Miller urged him and
Kelly to wait until next year's
session of the state legislature
to introduce the bill, due to the
large backlog of critical issues
facing the legislature, such as
drugs, education and the
budget.
In spite of this delay, Stude
remained undeterred. "I'll
keep proposing it until the day
I die," said Stude, who is
president of Pridemaster Inc.,
a Baltimore marketing and
advertising firm, and whose
father, Fritz Stude, played for
Johns Hopkins from 1928 to
1932.
But this setback is only the
latest in a series that lacrosse
and its devotees in Maryland
have had to suffer since 1962,
when Gov. J. Millard Tawes
signed a bill making jousting
Maryland's first state sport.
Although at that time lacrosse
was already considerably
popular, Tawes claimed that
the uniqueness of jousting
would help spur tourists' interest in Maryland.
Ifjousting had any effect on
tourism in Maryland is undocumented, but the years
since then have seen interest in
lacrosse both in Maryland and
across the nation increase
dramatically. Last year's
NCAA Division I men's
lacrosse championship game
between Johns Hopkins and
Syracuse drew 23,893 spectators to the University of
Maryland at College Park.
But jousting supporters in
Maryland, made up of the approximately fifty members of

the Maryland Tournament
Jousting Association, have
proved to be formidable opponents in the state government, although both Gov.
William Donald Schaefer and
Baltimore Mayor Kurt
Schmoke played lacrosse at
City College in Baltimore, and
the latter also at Yale
University.
Attempts to change the
nomenclature of the 1962 bill
by State Del. William J.
Burkhead (D-Anne Arundel
County) were voted down in
both 1980 and 1982. More
recently, a 1988 bill also sponsored by Kelly proposing to
completely replace jousting
with lacrosse as the state sport
never even received enough
votes in a hearing by the House
Constitutional and Administrative Law Committee to
become introduced into the
legislature.
One of the reasons for the
state government's opposition
to lacrosse is the conception a
large number of state
legislators hold that lacrosse is
an excessively violent sport.
"It's the closest thing to
controlled murder that I know
of," said Montgomery County Council President William
Hanna in a Jan. 25 article in
the Washington Post. Added
Hanna, "I never think of
Maryland as having anything
to do with lacrosse."
Many lacrosse supporters
feel, however, that this is a

misrepresented and misinformed conception of lacrosse,
most likely due to the advertisements for and image surrounding the Major Indoor
Lacrosse League (MILL).
Teams in the MILL play box
lacrosse, a hybrid between
lacrosse and ice hockey, which
is promoted as being extremely
violent.
"I have a big beef against
the whole sport because that is
the one segment of lacrosse
that is receiving some television time, airing time, advertising time, and all they show
are guys running into each
other . . . it's definitely different than field lacrosse,"
said Johns Hopkins men's
lacrosse coach Don Zimmerman. "And I in no way support or will ever support that
sport."
Another reason for opposition from many state
legislators to making lacrosse
the state sport is the time and
money which must be spent by
the state government in passing and putting into effect a bill
which, in the eyes of many,
has no consequence.
Lacrosse supporters respond, however, that if the state
had time and money to make
jousting the state sport in 1982,
it should have the time and
money in 1990 to also
recognize lacrosse.
"Issues which concern you
and me like drugs are definitely more important (than

lacrosse], but this world goes
around largely because of
things which 'really don't matter,— said Stude.
In addition, the fact that
more Maryland high school
students receive college
scholarships to play lacrosse
than any other sport makes
lacrosse deserving of the state
sport designation in the eyes of
many lacrosse supporters.
"I don't think many of these
kids would be able to joust
their way to college," added
Stude.
Whether or not lacrosse ever
receives any form of the state
sport designation, its supporters feel it will continue to
gain in popularity and will
always be their favorite sport.
"I think it would be nice if
somehow the state were to
somehow recognize lacrosse as
the state sport," said Zimmerman. "But lacrosse is not a
professional game, and I think
that because it's an amateur
sport it has retained some of
the beauty of sport for sport."
"The guys who come here
[to Hopkins] to play lacrosse,
they know that they're not going to leave here and sign
million-dollar contracts to play
professional lacrosse," added
Zimmerman. "They play the
sport for the love of the game.
And to me, that's the essence
of sports. And I think this
country is losing that."

by Bill Berger
Women's Fencing
The women's fencing team
claimed second place in the UAA
Championships last weekend.
While New York University
trounced everybody to take the
trophy, Hopkins dominated Case
Western Reserve and Brandeis to
compile a 2-1 match record in the
tournament.
In individual competition,
senior Domenica Rotunda and
junior Keiko Akasofu advanced
to the final round and finished
fifth and sixth, respectively, to
complete a successful weekend.
Junior Regina Mitchell also fenced well, advancing to the
semifinal round.
This year's championship
paralleled that of last season as
NYU won the competition, with
Hopkins finishing second.
Hopkins defeated CWRU (13-3)
and Brandeis (12-4). However,
NYU destroyed Hopkins (14-2),
a far cry from last season's tough
9-7 win.
The women shined in the individual competition, placing two
fencers in the top six. Last
season, Hopkins was shut out in
the final round, placing no
fencers in the top six.
Men's Fencing
The UAA Championships
resulted in a disappointing thirdplace finish for the second consecutive season for the Blue Jays.
Hopkins (2-2) finished behind
New York University (4-0) and
Brandeis (3-1).

The weekend started well with

Previewing the Division I tournament

Orange, Jays, & Heels on top
by Andy Bilello
The 1990 season opens a
new decade of college lacrosse
full of questions and expectations. Will Syracuse win a
third consecutive national title?
Can Johns Hopkins bring the
championship back to
Homewood? Is it possible that
someone else will prevent
another meeting between the
Orange and Blue Jays?
I can tell you that in the
tight-knit small world of col
lege lacrosse it is just about impossible for a new kid to crash
the big party and come away
with a natianal championship.
In 1990, expect the usual contenders and pretenders for the
title to compete for NCAA
tournament bids and the Final
Four at Rutgers, May 26-28.
There are five teams—
Syracuse, Hopkins, North
Carolina, Loyola, and
Virginia—with the talent to
win the championship. What
will determine the champion is
which team peaks at the right
time and has the dominant
player that can take control of
a game at crunch time.
After this group there are
approximately a dozen teams
in contention for the seven remaining tournament berths.
While several of these teams
are quite capable of upsetting
someone's trip to the Final
Four, it is unlikely that any of
them have the overall talent to
string together a championship
run.
The following is a closer
look at one view of how the
I2-team NCAA tournament
field will be filled in May.
I. SYRACUSE
The Gaits. When lacrosse
people talk about Syracuse's

twin All-America midfielders,
Gary and Paul Gait, they speak
in hushed toes as if "The
Gaits" were a new street gang
or an invading horde of barbarians. They are two of the
few college lacrosse players
with the size and speed of bigtime running backs. Added to
their intimidating physical
presence, the Gait boys bring
the dazzling stick skills honed
in the box lacrosse leagues of
their native British Columbia.
Any way you look at it both
Gary and Paul Gait are
outstanding lacrosse players
and Syracuse has them to
spearhead its run-and-gun
offense.
However, before pronouncing Syracuse national champions let us remember that
Gary and Paul are both human,
as Dave Pietramala helped
demonstrate, and that the
Orange are forced to field
eight other players. Syracuse's
"eight other players" are pretty good as well. At midfield,
the Orange can also depend
upon the speed of senior
Rodney
Dumpson and
Maryland transfer Tom
Gilmartin.
On attack the Orange return
second-team All-America Tom
Marachek, as well as seniors
Greg Burns and Jim Egan.
This group is dangerous and
experienced but lost to graduation first-team All-America
John Zulberti. The Orange
have enough firepower to
replace Zulberti's goal scoring
but his absence also leaves a
leadership void on the field
that might not be as easily
replaced.
The biggest challenge for
Coach Roy Simmons, Jr. will
be to solidify a defense that lost
three of its to four players.

Bill Berger

Scott Marr takes a diving shot in the Choice Visa Classic last October.
However, the one returning
defender is first-team AllAmerica Pat McCabe.
McCabe, a high school teammate of Hopkins' Matt
Panetta, may be the best
defenseman in the nation this
year. In goal Simmons will
have a tough decision between
incumbent Matt Palumb, who
has minded the nets in two
NCAA title games, and
sophomore Jerry DeLorenzo,
who many lacrosse insiders
consider more talented. The
question remains whether
Syracuse can play disciplined
defense when faced with a
tight game and a talented opponent that will not rollover.
The Orangemen have the
game's most talented roster,
the money ballplayers, and the
confidence that comes with
championship experience.
There is no doubt that
Syracuse is the team to beat.

Coach Don Zimmerman has a
team with the ability to
challenge for the title once
again.
Hopkins' success begins
with outstanding defense, and
the defense starts with the
goalkeeper. No one has a better goalie than Hopkins' Quint
Kessenich. Kessenich, a twotime first-team All-America,
not only makes all the plays he
should, but is also capable of
putting together the type of hot
streak that can carry a team in
the tournament. The close
defense will miss AllEverything Dave Pietramala to
be sure, but there is enough
talent to round-out an excellent
unit. Junior Bill Dwan earned
All-America honors last
season and is ready for a big
James

after missing last season with

counted on for his experience.

and Steve McMahon, is
talented but inexperienced.
How quickly Hopkins' young
defenders adapt to the college
game will greatly determine
the team's success.
At midfield Hopkins needs

sophomores Adam Wright and

The loose and confident Tar
Heels are one of the most difficult teams in the country to
figure out. They often
underachieve in the regular
season and end up seeded
lower than their talent deserves
in the NCAA's. Then UNC
will upset a higher seed (such
as Loyola last season) and
make a serious challenge for
the championship. The Tar
Heels should be no easier to
predict in '90.
North Carolina is once again
a dangerous offensivp team
with a world of athletic ability. In addition, the Heels may
have a little bit of wounded
pride since they have not
played in a title game since
winning the championship in
1986. Last season UNC fell
10-6 to Hopkins in the NCAA
semifinals.
Coach Willie Scroggs has a
potent offense returning led by
attackmen Dennis Goldstein
and Michael Thomas. Goldstein gave the Hopkins defense
nightmares with seven goals in
their two mettings last year.
The junior appears ready to
follow in the footsteps of his

Nichols, and Chris Gunkel.

hands with honorable mention

defender Gary Beach. The
close defense also welcomes
back starter Sean Quinn and
experienced players Scott
Oslislo and Tom Johnson. The
long-stick midfield has senior
Chris McGovern and soph

duty.
Overall the Greyhounds are
returning one of the most experienced groups of players in
the country and they appear
ready for a push into the bigtime. Inside word has it that

Loyola definitely has the
ability to contend for the

A time-honored tradition:

The Hopkins Band plays on
by Christopher Bonanos
Since the late 1920's, the
Johns Hopkins band has
played at virtually every Blue
Jays lacrosse game. Even in
the pouring spring rains for
which Baltimore is famous, the
band stays by the team, playing and cheering until the final
whistle.
The band has a remarkable
level of alumni loyalty as well.
Especially, at Homecoming,
former members of the group
return to play at the games.
Some alumni have been coming back for over twenty years.
Although new songs are
added from time to time, the
band's repertoire remains consistent. Certain Hopkins fight
songs have been around for
decades. "To Win" is played
every time Hopkins scores a
goal; fans and alumni sing
along. (The song changes to
"Ach, Du Lieber" after 20
goals, and the "Beer Barrel
Polka" at 25.)
After the song ends, a chant

begins, counting off the
number of goals scored so far
and adding "We want more!"
at the end. "Johnny Hopkins
On To Victory" is heard when
the team comes onto the field
at the start of each half and
again at the end of the game.
John
Phillip
Sousa's
"Washington Post" march is

played as the crowd files out.
Also, older players and fans
often request "On the Line,"
a fight song from the early part
of this century.
A number of long-standing,
if unusual, traditions surround
the band as well. Probably the
most famous—or infamous—
of these is the "banana goal."

In the fourth quarter of every
lacrosse game, the band
members and diehard lacrosse
groupies try to gauge which
will be the final goal. If
Hopkins is already far ahead,
the first goal of the fourth
quarter is chosen. The musicians and fans each take a
banana and eagerly wait.

When the goal is scored, the
fans cheer wildly, waving the
bananas, sing along with "To
Win," and eat their bananas.
The player scoring the goal
usually receives a thrown
banana as well. Rumor has it
that the tradition began when
a game-winning, come-frombehind victory took place just
as a lacrosse fan was peeling
a banana for lunch. Admittedly, there's no real point to this
practice, but it's a great
tradition.
Perhaps it is indicative of the
band's strong presence in
Hopkins lacrosse history that
the stadium on Homewood
Field is named not for a
lacrosse hero or wealthy alumnus but for the the band's
original conductor, Conrad
Gebelein. "Gebby" conducted
the band from its ROTCoffshoot beginnings in the
1920's until his retirement in
1971.

Though both the men's and
women's teams grace the same
Homewood turf to partake in
the unofficial state sport of
Maryland, two entirely different games are played.
On days when the Hopkins
women come to play, there are
no boundaries and no limitations to where players can go
on the field. The twelve
women (as opposed to ten
men) play on until a ball is
whistled out-of-bounds or
dead. At that point, with the
exception of the goalkeeper,
all athletes on the field stop and
remain stationary until the
whistle blows again to resume
play. The player closest to the
ball when it is called out takes
control of play (as in a shoton-goal for the men).
There is no body contact in
women's lacrosse. Women do
not wear protective gear with
the exception of a mouth guard
and thin gloves which cannot
extend the size of the hand.
Although body checks are
disallowed, stick checks away
from the head and not deemed dangerous are permitted.

The Hopkins Applied Physics
Laboratory (APL) in Laurel,
Maryland, is currently analyzing
data from a successful satellite
tracking experiment for the
Strategic Defense Initiative, commonly known as 'Star Wars,' or
SDI.
Crucial to the success of the
SDI shield against nuclear
weapons is the quick and accurate
detection and tracking of Soviet
or Chinese nuclear missile launches. In the boost phase of a
nuclear missile's journey into orbit, the rocket exhausts hot gases
in a plume. These gases are
detectable primarily in the infrared region. Under an SDI umbrella, these rocket plumes,
known as the "signature" of the
missile, would be detected by

satellites. These satellites would
then guide other weapons to
destroy the missiles.
APL's Delta Star project was
designed to address these
issues—in the Pentagon's jargon,
Surveillance, Acquisition, Tracking, and Kilt Assessment
(SATKA). The News-Letter interviewed APL's Delta Star project manager for this article. Additional information was provided by APL's external relations officer, Frank Proctor.
The Delta Star 183 satellite,
which was designed and assembled in Laurel at APL, was launched on March 24, 1989 on a
Delta
McDonnell-Douglas
rocket. The Delta booster is the
military's preferred vehicle for
space missions. While in low
earth orbit, the Delta Star satellite
collected data on gaseous plumes

emitted by sounding rockets launched from Wallops Island,
Virginia, and from Alaska. The
plumes were designed to simulate
the rocket plumes of Soviet intercontinental and submarinelaunched ballistic missiles. Data
collection ended on December
21, 1989, six months past the intended lifetime of the satellite.
The Delta Star satellite's sensors measured the rocket plumes'
radiation
characteristics
throughout
the
optical
spectrum--infrared, visible, and
ultraviolet ranges. Past SDI
research has focused on the infrared, which is the dominant

By Christopher T. McColl
The punchline is this: the scrapheap.
I have tons of work to do, and
I really don't have time to write
a thematically sound column, so
this week's installment will consist of all those ideas that I'd really like to develop into complete
columns, but can't for whatever
reason.
I guess thematically, we could
call it "Those Aspects of Human
Existence that Chris Finds Most
Peculiar."
One of the most peculiar
things, for me, at least, is the fact
that facial tissue is about four
times the size of bathroom
tissue—and twice as thick. Consider this: you get an eight-inch
by eight-inch four-ply square for
your nose (the biggest honker requiring maybe ten square inches
at most) but you get a four-byfour one-ply square, albeit a
rough ply most of the time, for
your derriere (I won't speculate
on what size the largest tush
might need).
Number two: snarfing. It is
said that in some countries, it is
common courtesy to belch after
a good meal, and most
Americans, I think, would find
that gross. By the same token,
however, I have found that many
Americans consider it a tremendous achievement if they can get
one of their close friends to snarf
at a meal, an achievement worthy of countless anecdotal repetitions to those other close friends
who might have missed the event.
Editor's Note to those Belching
Visitors to Our Fine Country
Who Might Not Know What the
Verb "To Snarf" Means, Let
Alone How to Conjugate It: It is
an odd fact of the human anatomy
that when faced with possible
asphyxiation by combining
laughter with commonly imbibed fluids, the brain has the ability to register the embarassment
factor of said fluid in the event of
death (i.e. it is much cooler to die
"choking violently on a dry martini" than to die "gagging,
moustache-laden, on 2% milk.").

Given that a particular drink is
just too hysterical to let somebody
die on, the brain will cause a sudden and jarring peristaltic twitch,
forcing said drink back up,
hopefully, through the mouth. In
the event that this mouth is not
busy laughing, the result will be
a "saliva tocarum," more commonly called a "spit take." If the
mouth is laughing, however, the
tongue will be pressed against the
esophagus, and the drink will be
forced out another egress, namely, the nose. The passage from
esophagus to nose is an intricate
one, filled with many organs
designed to transform ordinary
food into mucous-based lifeforms. The emergence of these
life-forms is "snarfing."
Third, of course, is elevatorbutton-punching, best illustrated
thusly: Person approaches
Elevator. Person pushes "up"
button, thus alerting Elevator of
his/her presence. Elevator, on
another floor, may take ten or
twelve seconds to arrive. Person,
angered that Elevator was not
notified earlier of his arrival,
strikes on the notion that perhaps
pressing the "up" button 9,000
more times will make it arrive
faster. This act is usually coupled with a glance up at the ceiling
in order that Person, capable of
vision through solids, might
watch Elevator's hurried approach. This activity was what
prompted me to submit the
Stupidity Bill to Congress, in
order to mandate a "Slap Law."
The "Slap Law" gives
pedestrians the rights and responsibilities of deputies when acts of
stupidity are witnessed. A
pedestrian witnessing someone in
front of an elevator, for example,
tapping the drum solo to
"Wipeout" on the call button
with head upturned, would have
the duty of stopping the person
immediately and slapping him or
her across the face, winning
another battle in the war against
stupidity.

The Women's Center woulo
like to address the many
misconceptions and accusations
concerning the "2x +1" cartoon
strip. As stated several times, the
group of students who went to the
administration went on their own
behalf, and not as representatives
of the Women's Center. This
represents a positive trend in the
attitude of the student body, that
individuals would feel strongly

would feel comfortable enough to
go to an administrator and voice

The Women's Center sent out
a flyer asking the Hopkins community if they thought this cartoon was appropriate, and we
stand behind this action. The flyer
was offensive only to the extent
that the cartoon was offensive,
but at least in the context of the
flyer the attitude was questioned,
rather than accepted.
The members of the Women's
Center are dismayed to find that
instead of addressing the issue of
sexism that this cartoon presents,
this campus has successfully
thrown up a smoke screen in the
guise of the censorship issue.
Focusing the argument on censorship is convenient in that no one
is threatened, except perhaps the
editors of campus publications.
The fact is that many people are
uncomfortable discussing issues
of discrimination because of the
basic reality that in order to provide equality, the dominating
group will have to relinquish
some of its precious control.
Whether we are referring to an
Aryan race or a patriarchy, those
who dominate will try to avoid
discussing the issue.
The issue here is sexism, and
it is so pervasive and omnipresent
that we have trouble identifying
it as such, much less addressing
it constructively in the form of
dialogue within this intellectual
community. If this strip had
targeted any other minority group
on campus, it would not have

been printed.

cartoon by the same artist submitted to the Spectator, but because
of space restrictions it was not
printed. The alternative strip
presented an issue similar to the
one in the printed cartoon, but it
was aimed at the men of Johns
Hopkins instead of the women.

the cartoon that they found to be
the most humorous. Obviously it
is funnier, or more accepted, to
mock women than men.

offend. The artist even told us to
whom we should address hate
mail. We question the intent of
this article. It seems that there
must be more mature and meaningful ways to address the issue

community is truly the intent. The

discriminatory. Threatened by intelligent women, some people attempt to diminish their worth by

discrimination today. By unconsciously accepting these views

Americans, Jews, Puerto Ricans,
homosexuals, and women we are
subordinating these groups. We
hope that any future discussion of
the "2x +1" article will focus on
the real issue at hand.

primary goal is not to accuse. We
are a resource center for anyone
interested in women's issues.
March is International Women's
,Month and we will be sponsoring several events to celebrate
women's solidarity. Although
problems of sexism still exist, we
would like to encourage a more
positive approach to women's
issues, and we invite you all(men
and women alike) to attend our
upcoming events.

PUNCH, from 5
My fourth thesis refers to the
habit so many people have of
reacting to weekly television
series in which the main character
is placed in some sort of peril,
such as MacGyver's weekly stint
with a laser aimed at his pancreas
and the like. Anyone honestly
tense in moments like this might
consult his TV Guide. If the
show's slated to appear the
following week, and especially if
it's still called "MacGyver,"
chances are he'll muddle through.
Interruptive question: Is there
going to be a "fortysomething"

episode on the tenth anniversary
of "thirtysomething'"? Or is this
really "Pippi Longstocking Goes
Into Advertising and Social
Activisomething'"?
Last is the inclination everyone
seems to feel to peel the
wax/foam label off a soda bottle
when it's empty. I have recently
been informed that this stems out
of a feeling of social frustration.
I have a feeling that the idea
started with the same group of
people who spread around the
"chewing ice is said to be a sign
of sexual frustration" myth. My
hypothesis concerning this group

is that they all look like toads and
couldn't find a date if they bought
a calendar, but have trained
themselves through aversion
therapy and acupuncture not to
peel labels off bottles and not to
chew ice when their soda is gone;
that way, they could all claim to
be more carnally rampant than
their truly satisfied friends. My
suggestion for these people is to
stop sticking themselves with pins
and live wires—they'll be more
attractive, and the rest of us will
be able to get back to our nervous
habits without feeling selfconscious.

FIVE-YEAR PLAN
Some grad students have been
concerned of late as to whether
the GRO will get a chance to meet
the new University President, Dr.
William C. Richardson. Apparently, according to Joanne
Houlahan, this should be possible. Further, she said, her discussions as part of the Armstrong
committee had led her to believe
that Richardson has a keen interest in revamping the teaching
of graduate students at Hopkins.
especially with .a view to getting
PhD students, through quicker.
This however brings one to the
problem of what many perceive
de eartIS a trend towards man

ments' becoming little more than
"service departments," meaning
that they are concerned with
churning out undergrads as
quickly as possible with little emphasis on new research. Departments that have particularly
suffered, it is generally agreed,
include the language departments
and Biology. The latter used once
to require a lab for each class at
the undergrad level. Now the
students can get away with taking only two lab classes for the
B.A., and they are only required
fro those taking classes to get into med school.
This problem has been intensified by the five-year plan's enforcement of a ten percent cut in
faculty numbers, to be acheived
through attrition. Thus important
vacancies may well remain unfilled. Certainly, they will not be
automatically filled. As things
stand now, since the implementation of the plan, departments
with recent vacancies must petition to have them filled. Arts &
Sciences Dean Lloyd Armstrong
decides each case on an ad hoc
basis. To say the least, this would
certainly seem to go against the
grain of what incoming-president
Richardson is purported to want.
The bind the school finds itself
in is simple. Undergrads provide
revenue. Grads do not.
Moreover, some subjects are currently in high demand with
undergrads, such as International
Relations. The school is therefore
pressure—economic
under
pressure, if nothing else—to let
undergrads into these majors in
greater numbers as a way of increasing the cash flowing into
Arts & Sciences. So far, so good.
The problem lies in the fact that
Hopkins' reputation is built on its
status as a research institution,
rather than a place of teaching.
Hopkins always has been, and
still is, a cross between a college
and a think-tank. But its name
rests on that think-tank component. However, other researchoriented establishments have far
larger endowments than Hopkins
has. We cannot afford not to
teach larger and larger numbers

_
of undergrads.
And yet we don't cio a particularly good job of it. For this
comes at a time when many professors are trying to shed some of
their advising responsibility due
to the amount of research time it
cuts into. Since 1975, there has
been a staggering 70 percent drop
in the proportion of undergrads
taking the honors option, which
includes for the most part an individually supervised senior
thesis. On top of this, the Office
of Acedemic Advising, which
does an excellent job under the
most adverse of circumstances, is
encouraging students to rely on
their own departments' council,
rather than the less specific advice
offered by Academic Advising.
In some departments, it has
become common for advising
responsibilities to be given over
to grad students; the profs no
longer have the time.
All of which puts more
pressure on the long-suffering
grad population. Smaller
stipends, because of financial
cuts. Greater teaching—and now,
advising—loads, because of the
ten-percent cut in faculty. Wayda
go, Steve.
The cumulative result will
simply be that Hopkins' name
plummets still further. Grad
students must no longer be taken
for granted. Hopkins must either
continue to let grads in at the current fairly high rate, while
guaranteeing them enough funding to get through their programs quickly, without having to
resort to teaching and outside jobs
to support themselves. Or it must
drastically reduce the number of
grads admitted, while agreeing to
fund them for longer as each grad
soaks up an inevitably larger
teaching load.
Either path will do. The current
one will not. For it is simply the
worst of all worlds.

Applications are currently being taken for the Louis
Azrael Fellowship in Communications, 3 one-year, $5000
scholarship for students who have demonstrated excellence
in journalism, radio, television, or other kinds of public
communications.
The fellowship, won in recent years by Hopkins'
students Sujata Banerjee, Todd Gillman, Frank Wu, Jay
Lechtman, Lisa Goldberg, Lisa Weisbord, Elizabeth
Brown, Sharyn Horowitz, Joshua Orenstein, Kimberly
Lankford, and Alexandra Pham, honors the memory of

distinguished for his work during World War II, especially for his account of D-Day. His war correspondence won
him a Medal of Freedom from President Dwight D.
Eisenhower.

Seminars, and will be judged by Professors Stephen Dixon, Mark Crispin Miller, Theo Lippmann, and Herbert

or juniors, and must be nominated by a faculty member.
This may come in the form of a direct nomination by the
faculty member, or a self-nomination by the student with
a letter of recommendation from a faculty member.
Students should submit manuscripts of 15 to 30 pages,
with their letters of sponsorship, to The Writing Seminars.

vita, a statement about current interests and some prospectus for future career plans. For more information please

co-ordinator of the seminar,
stated that abortion would be "the
political issue of the 1990's,"
especially after the 1989 Supreme
Court Case of Webster v.
Reproductive Health Services.

In their decision on this issue,
the court chose to give individual
states the right to legislate and reject the rights of women to have
abortions. It showed an "interest
in prenatal life at .the risk of
women's bodies," and has led to
changes in the abortion policies
of many individual states.
As co-ordinator of this

three speakers who spoke on the
repercussions of the Supreme
Court's decision. The speakers
were Professor Sylvia Law, of
the NYU Law School, Professor
Faye Ginsberg, NYU Department of Anthropology, and Jean-

nie I. Rosoff, from the Alan Guftmacher Institute. After the three
lectures concluded, a round-table
discussion was held with the three
speakers as well as with Ms.
Poovey and Connie Nathanson
and Lorna Thorpe, two members
of the. Hopkins community.
Professor Sylvia Law's lecture
was the most Interesting of the
three. Law worked as a historian
for the case of Webster v.
Reproductive Health Services,
researching the history of abortion in the United States. She
chose to work on this case
because she knew that a loss

A new state sport for Md?
by Weijen Chang
Most Marylanders know that
the state bird is the oriole, that
the state flowet is the blackeyed susan, and that the state
sport is—jousting? While
many Marylanders might think
"lacrosse" would be a better
answer, jousting remains the
state sport of Maryland,
despite a recent attempt by
lacrosse advocates to give
lacrosse at least a share of
jousting's title.
Under pressure from State
Senate President Thomas
"Mike" Millc'. (D-Prince
Georges County), supporters
of a bill proposing to designate
lacrosse the state team sport
decided not to introduce it for
consideration by the legislature
this year. The bill, sponsored
by State Sen. Frank Kelly(DBaltimore County), would retain jousting as the state individual sport.
According to John Stude,
one of the bill's chief supporters, Miller urged him and
Kelly to wait until next year's
session of the state legislature
to introduce the bill, due to the
large backlog of critical issues
facing the legislature, such as
drugs, education and the
budget.
In spite of this delay, Stude
remained undeterred. "I'll
keep proposing it until the day
I die," said Stude, who is
president of Pridemaster Inc.,
a Baltimore marketing and
advertising firm, and whose
father, Fritz Stude, played for
Johns Hopkins from 1928 to
1932.
But this setback is only the
latest in a series that lacrosse
and its devotees in Maryland
have had to suffer since 1962,
when Gov. J. Millard Tawes
signed a bill making jousting
Maryland's first state sport.
Although at that time lacrosse
was already considerably
popular, Tawes claimed that
the uniqueness of jousting
would help spur tourists' interest in Maryland.
Ifjousting had any effect on
tourism in Maryland is undocumented, but the years
since then have seen interest in
lacrosse both in Maryland and
across the nation increase
dramatically. Last year's
NCAA Division I men's
lacrosse championship game
between Johns Hopkins and
Syracuse drew 23,893 spectators to the University of
Maryland at College Park.
But jousting supporters in
Maryland, made up of the approximately fifty members of

the Maryland Tournament
Jousting Association, have
proved to be formidable opponents in the state government, although both Gov.
William Donald Schaefer and
Baltimore Mayor Kurt
Schmoke played lacrosse at
City College in Baltimore, and
the latter also at Yale
University.
Attempts to change the
nomenclature of the 1962 bill
by State Del. William J.
Burkhead (D-Anne Arundel
County) were voted down in
both 1980 and 1982. More
recently, a 1988 bill also sponsored by Kelly proposing to
completely replace jousting
with lacrosse as the state sport
never even received enough
votes in a hearing by the House
Constitutional and Administrative Law Committee to
become introduced into the
legislature.
One of the reasons for the
state government's opposition
to lacrosse is the conception a
large number of state
legislators hold that lacrosse is
an excessively violent sport.
"It's the closest thing to
controlled murder that I know
of," said Montgomery County Council President William
Hanna in a Jan. 25 article in
the Washington Post. Added
Hanna, "I never think of
Maryland as having anything
to do with lacrosse."
Many lacrosse supporters
feel, however, that this is a

misrepresented and misinformed conception of lacrosse,
most likely due to the advertisements for and image surrounding the Major Indoor
Lacrosse League (MILL).
Teams in the MILL play box
lacrosse, a hybrid between
lacrosse and ice hockey, which
is promoted as being extremely
violent.
"I have a big beef against
the whole sport because that is
the one segment of lacrosse
that is receiving some television time, airing time, advertising time, and all they show
are guys running into each
other . . . it's definitely different than field lacrosse,"
said Johns Hopkins men's
lacrosse coach Don Zimmerman. "And I in no way support or will ever support that
sport."
Another reason for opposition from many state
legislators to making lacrosse
the state sport is the time and
money which must be spent by
the state government in passing and putting into effect a bill
which, in the eyes of many,
has no consequence.
Lacrosse supporters respond, however, that if the state
had time and money to make
jousting the state sport in 1982,
it should have the time and
money in 1990 to also
recognize lacrosse.
"Issues which concern you
and me like drugs are definitely more important (than

lacrosse], but this world goes
around largely because of
things which 'really don't matter,— said Stude.
In addition, the fact that
more Maryland high school
students receive college
scholarships to play lacrosse
than any other sport makes
lacrosse deserving of the state
sport designation in the eyes of
many lacrosse supporters.
"I don't think many of these
kids would be able to joust
their way to college," added
Stude.
Whether or not lacrosse ever
receives any form of the state
sport designation, its supporters feel it will continue to
gain in popularity and will
always be their favorite sport.
"I think it would be nice if
somehow the state were to
somehow recognize lacrosse as
the state sport," said Zimmerman. "But lacrosse is not a
professional game, and I think
that because it's an amateur
sport it has retained some of
the beauty of sport for sport."
"The guys who come here
[to Hopkins] to play lacrosse,
they know that they're not going to leave here and sign
million-dollar contracts to play
professional lacrosse," added
Zimmerman. "They play the
sport for the love of the game.
And to me, that's the essence
of sports. And I think this
country is losing that."

Previewing the Division I tournament

Orange, Jays, & Heels on top
by Andy Bilello
The 1990 season opens a
new decade of college lacrosse
full of questions and expectations. Will Syracuse win a
third consecutive national title?
Can Johns Hopkins bring the
championship back to
Homewood? Is it possible that
someone else will prevent
another meeting between the
Orange and Blue Jays?
I can tell you that in the
tight-knit small world of col
lege lacrosse it is just about impossible for a new kid to crash
the big party and come away
with a natianal championship.
In 1990, expect the usual contenders and pretenders for the
title to compete for NCAA
tournament bids and the Final
Four at Rutgers, May 26-28.
There are five teams—
Syracuse, Hopkins, North
Carolina, Loyola, and
Virginia—with the talent to
win the championship. What
will determine the champion is
which team peaks at the right
time and has the dominant
player that can take control of
a game at crunch time.
After this group there are
approximately a dozen teams
in contention for the seven remaining tournament berths.
While several of these teams
are quite capable of upsetting
someone's trip to the Final
Four, it is unlikely that any of
them have the overall talent to
string together a championship
run.
The following is a closer
look at one view of how the
I2-team NCAA tournament
field will be filled in May.
I. SYRACUSE
The Gaits. When lacrosse
people talk about Syracuse's

twin All-America midfielders,
Gary and Paul Gait, they speak
in hushed toes as if "The
Gaits" were a new street gang
or an invading horde of barbarians. They are two of the
few college lacrosse players
with the size and speed of bigtime running backs. Added to
their intimidating physical
presence, the Gait boys bring
the dazzling stick skills honed
in the box lacrosse leagues of
their native British Columbia.
Any way you look at it both
Gary and Paul Gait are
outstanding lacrosse players
and Syracuse has them to
spearhead its run-and-gun
offense.
However, before pronouncing Syracuse national champions let us remember that
Gary and Paul are both human,
as Dave Pietramala helped
demonstrate, and that the
Orange are forced to field
eight other players. Syracuse's
"eight other players" are pretty good as well. At midfield,
the Orange can also depend
upon the speed of senior
Rodney
Dumpson and
Maryland transfer Tom
Gilmartin.
On attack the Orange return
second-team All-America Tom
Marachek, as well as seniors
Greg Burns and Jim Egan.
This group is dangerous and
experienced but lost to graduation first-team All-America
John Zulberti. The Orange
have enough firepower to
replace Zulberti's goal scoring
but his absence also leaves a
leadership void on the field
that might not be as easily
replaced.
The biggest challenge for
Coach Roy Simmons, Jr. will
be to solidify a defense that lost
three of its to four players.

Bill Berger

Scott Marr takes a diving shot in the Choice Visa Classic last October.
However, the one returning
defender is first-team AllAmerica Pat McCabe.
McCabe, a high school teammate of Hopkins' Matt
Panetta, may be the best
defenseman in the nation this
year. In goal Simmons will
have a tough decision between
incumbent Matt Palumb, who
has minded the nets in two
NCAA title games, and
sophomore Jerry DeLorenzo,
who many lacrosse insiders
consider more talented. The
question remains whether
Syracuse can play disciplined
defense when faced with a
tight game and a talented opponent that will not rollover.
The Orangemen have the
game's most talented roster,
the money ballplayers, and the
confidence that comes with
championship experience.
There is no doubt that
Syracuse is the team to beat.

Coach Don Zimmerman has a
team with the ability to
challenge for the title once
again.
Hopkins' success begins
with outstanding defense, and
the defense starts with the

Kessenich. Kessenich, a twotime first-team All-America,
not only makes all the plays he
should, but is also capable of
putting together the type of hot
streak that can carry a team in
the tournament. The close
defense will miss AllEverything Dave Pietramala to
be sure, but there is enough
talent to round-out an excellent
unit. Junior Bill Dwan earned
All-America honors last
season and is ready for a big

will upset a higher seed (such

predict in '90.
North Carolina is once again
a dangerous offensivp team

have a little bit of wounded
pride since they have not
played in a title game since
winning the championship in
1986. Last season UNC fell
10-6 to Hopkins in the NCAA
semifinals.
Coach Willie Scroggs has a
potent offense returning led by

and Michael Thomas. Goldstein gave the Hopkins defense
nightmares with seven goals in

follow in the footsteps of his

defender Gary Beach. The
close defense also welcomes
back starter Sean Quinn and
experienced players Scott
Oslislo and Tom Johnson. The
long-stick midfield has senior
Chris McGovern and soph

duty.
Overall the Greyhounds are
returning one of the most experienced groups of players in
the country and they appear

Loyola definitely has the
ability to contend for the

A time-honored tradition:

The Hopkins Band plays on
by Christopher Bonanos
Since the late 1920's, the
Johns Hopkins band has
played at virtually every Blue
Jays lacrosse game. Even in
the pouring spring rains for
which Baltimore is famous, the
band stays by the team, playing and cheering until the final
whistle.
The band has a remarkable
level of alumni loyalty as well.
Especially, at Homecoming,
former members of the group
return to play at the games.
Some alumni have been coming back for over twenty years.
Although new songs are
added from time to time, the
band's repertoire remains consistent. Certain Hopkins fight
songs have been around for
decades. "To Win" is played
every time Hopkins scores a
goal; fans and alumni sing
along. (The song changes to
"Ach, Du Lieber" after 20
goals, and the "Beer Barrel
Polka" at 25.)
After the song ends, a chant

begins, counting off the
number of goals scored so far
and adding "We want more!"
at the end. "Johnny Hopkins
On To Victory" is heard when
the team comes onto the field
at the start of each half and
again at the end of the game.
John
Phillip
Sousa's
"Washington Post" march is

played as the crowd files out.
Also, older players and fans
often request "On the Line,"
a fight song from the early part
of this century.
A number of long-standing,
if unusual, traditions surround
the band as well. Probably the
most famous—or infamous—
of these is the "banana goal."

In the fourth quarter of every
lacrosse game, the band
members and diehard lacrosse
groupies try to gauge which
will be the final goal. If
Hopkins is already far ahead,
the first goal of the fourth
quarter is chosen. The musicians and fans each take a
banana and eagerly wait.

When the goal is scored, the
fans cheer wildly, waving the
bananas, sing along with "To
Win," and eat their bananas.
The player scoring the goal
usually receives a thrown
banana as well. Rumor has it
that the tradition began when
a game-winning, come-frombehind victory took place just
as a lacrosse fan was peeling
a banana for lunch. Admittedly, there's no real point to this
practice, but it's a great
tradition.
Perhaps it is indicative of the
band's strong presence in
Hopkins lacrosse history that
the stadium on Homewood
Field is named not for a
lacrosse hero or wealthy alumnus but for the the band's
original conductor, Conrad
Gebelein. "Gebby" conducted
the band from its ROTCoffshoot beginnings in the
1920's until his retirement in
1971.

The women's game:

A lax comparison
by Rachel McGuckian
Though both the men's and
women's teams grace the same
Homewood turf to partake in
the unofficial state sport of
Maryland, two entirely different games are played.
On days when the Hopkins
women come to play, there are
no boundaries and no limitations to where players can go
on the field. The twelve
women (as opposed to ten
men) play on until a ball is
whistled out-of-bounds or
dead. At that point, with the
exception of the goalkeeper,
all athletes on the field stop and
remain stationary until the
whistle blows again to resume
play. The player closest to the
ball when it is called out takes
control of play (as in a shoton-goal for the men).
There is no body contact in
women's lacrosse. Women do
not wear protective gear with
the exception of a mouth guard
and thin gloves which cannot
extend the size of the hand.
Although body checks are
disallowed, stick checks away
from the head and not deemed dangerous are permitted.
